## <i class="fa-solid fa-industry"></i> The Challenge

A technical components distributor with **8,000+ SKUs** had pricing chaos:

::: {.incremental}
- <i class="fa-solid fa-puzzle-piece"></i> Patchwork of cost-plus, competitor-matching, and forgotten prices
- <i class="fa-solid fa-percent"></i> Sales team had broad discounting authority → margin erosion
- <i class="fa-solid fa-database"></i> 60% of SKUs sold <50 units/year (sparse data)
- <i class="fa-solid fa-user-shield"></i> Sales culture resistant to "black box" pricing
:::

---

## <i class="fa-solid fa-lightbulb"></i> The Approach

Developed a **hierarchical pricing model** that works despite data sparsity:

::: {.incremental}
- <i class="fa-solid fa-sitemap"></i> **Category-level estimation:** Shrink SKU estimates toward category priors
- <i class="fa-solid fa-users"></i> **Customer segmentation:** Price-sensitive vs. relationship accounts
- <i class="fa-solid fa-signal"></i> **WTP signals:** Quote-to-order rates, discount request frequency
- <i class="fa-solid fa-eye"></i> **Transparent outputs:** Confidence intervals + plain-language explanations
:::

## <i class="fa-solid fa-key"></i> Key Insight

> B2B pricing isn't about finding the "right" price — it's about giving sales teams **defensible anchors**.

::: {.highlight-box style="margin-top: 1em;"}
<i class="fa-solid fa-comments"></i> A model that **explains its reasoning** gets adopted. A model that just outputs numbers gets ignored.
:::
